abstract: Shares of Vodafone fell in London trading on Wednesday after Verizon Communications said it did not “currently have any intention to merge with or make an offer for Vodafone, whether alone or in conjunction with others.”
snippet: Shares of Vodafone fell in London trading on Wednesday after Verizon Communications said it did not “currently have any intention to merge with or make an offer for Vodafone, whether alone or in conjunction with others.”
lead_paragraph: Shares of Vodafone fell in London trading on Wednesday after Verizon Communications said it did not “currently have any intention to merge with or make an offer for Vodafone, whether alone or in conjunction with others.”

headline.main: Vodafone Shares Fall After Verizon Throws Cold Water on Bid Talk

abstract: Twitter, Facebook and other sites are now legitimate ways for chief executives to communicate with investors, but within certain limits. | Two hedge funds waging proxy battles are planning to pay their director nominees as if they were chief executives. | In board rooms in fields like law, technology and private equity, women are still underrepresented. | Verizon quiets talk of a deal.
snippet: Twitter, Facebook and other sites are now legitimate ways for chief executives to communicate with investors, but within certain limits. | Two hedge funds waging proxy battles are planning to pay their director nominees as if they were chief execu...
lead_paragraph: Sites like Twitter and Facebook are now considered legitimate ways for chief executives to communicate with their investors, but within certain limits. The Securities and Exchange Commission outlined disclosure rules for social media, saying on Tuesday that companies could use the tools to convey important information as long as they informed investors about that strategy ahead of time, DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced reports.

abstract: T-Mobile, the smallest of the Big Four cellphone carriers, steps away from the two-year, unbreakable contract that Sprint, Verizon and AT&T live by.
snippet: T-Mobile, the smallest of the Big Four cellphone carriers, steps away from the two-year, unbreakable contract that Sprint, Verizon and AT&T live by.
lead_paragraph: Where, exactly, is your threshold for outrage?

headline.main: Breaking Free of the Cellphone Carrier Conspiracy
headline.print_headline: T-Mobile Breaks Free Of Carrier Conspiracy
